Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2015 08:27PM - edited Feb 14, 2015 08:29PM by VegasNurse I'm a icu nurse myself as well as a cancer patient....your liver and kidneys need to be functioning well and your body needs to be as strong as possible. Chemo is very toxic and can interact with many icu drugs. This can make her weaker and more unstable. She is at one of the top hospitals in the country. Trust in the doctors. They are the experts. I am praying for her and your family.

Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2015 01:57AM - edited Feb 12, 2015 01:58AM by VegasNurse I was diagnosed March 2014 after suffering a pathological fracture of my left hip over a small slip and fall. Stage four from the get go with mets to multiple bones. I'm 91 percent ER positive 5 percent PR positive. Her 2 neg. grade 2.Last pet scan last week showed no more active cancer. Thank you for this site and this forum.
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2015 11:29PM VegasNurse wrote: no problem. I remember when I was first diagnosed a year ago....I searched and searched for some glimmer of hope. The support group was one of the best things I did....stay strong sisters

Posts.Title: Well...bad news Cancersux1990 RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2015 08:15AM - edited Feb 13, 2015 08:17AM by VegasNurse hi ladies....I'm 39 with stage four breast cancer with mets to bone diagnosed on my birthday feb 28 2014 after a pathological hip fracture. I am now in a great support group at my local church. There are four ladies out of ten of us who have already lived a decade and more with stage four breast cancer. One of which is a triple negative gal. I am presently in Remission. I'm not going to focus on reoccurrence. I'm living life each day taking time to be thankful. Don't give up hope. Stage four isn't the death sentence it use to be
Posts.Title: Well...bad news Cancersux1990 RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2014 09:19PM VegasNurse wrote: my onc also said remission is when the tumors are shrinking and Ned is no evidence of disease.  I'm currently in remission...my bone mets are no longer detectable and I have a small lump in right breast that still shows uptake on pet scan.  Getting a double mastectomy next month.
Posts.Title: thoughts about difference between remission and NED reader123 leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2014 05:40PM VegasNurse wrote: hi....I had 15 rounds of radiation to my hips and pelvic.....sciatica pain is exactly what it was like for me.  Took until the 10 dose for me to feel the difference...plus the lortab is helping as well.
Posts.Title: Sciatica pain still exists after radiation therapy! shaM shaM

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2015 10:19PM - edited Feb 14, 2015 10:21PM by VegasNurse as a icu nurse I have seen how well modern medicine works. I had a wonderful friend who was diagnosed with triple negative bc and refused conventional medicine at stage one. Needless to say she only survived 8 months...it spread that fast on her so called homeopathic treatments. When she was told it spread from head to toe and to almost every organ, she was told it was too late and to far gone. I was diagnosed with a stage four with bone mets in February. Did chemo, now NED. I'm am true believer in modern medicine.
